newsitem.title: FRANCE: Cr Foncier legislation ready soon - Arthuis.
newsitem.headline: Cr Foncier legislation ready soon - Arthuis.

text.p: Legislation covering the next stage of the plan to wind-down property lending group Credit Foncier de France will be ready in a few weeks, French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis said on Wednesday.

French state bank Caisse des Depots took over Credit Foncier in December on the government's behalf in the first stage of the wind-down but staff, unions and some parliamentarians have been campaigning for the next stage to be put on hold.
The next stage involves legislation creating a state holding company to take over Foncier's bond commitments and spinning off its housing loans portfolio to Credit Immobilier de France.
"Credit Immobilier is the only one do this day to have made clear an interest in taking over the Credit Foncier network and management of the PAPs (low-cost housing loans) portfolio, Arthuis said.
His remarks were in an advance copy of a Wednesday afternoon address to a parliamentary committee, a copy of which was obtained by Reuters.

Arthuis said, according to the copy of his prepared address, that a legislative text, required to create the holding company that will take over Credit Foncier's bond obligations, would be ready for parliament in a "few weeks" after adoption by the cabinet.

Credit Foncier announced huge losses of 10.8 billion francs for 1995 after provisions for risky property investments and Arthuis unveiled the wind-down plan in July after failed attempts by the group to find a buyer.

But staff, unions, and a substantial number of parliament members have been campaigning for a stay of execution, arguing that the provisions in the 1995 accounts were overdone and pointing for forecasts for a one billion franc profit this year as proof that the group could be made viable.
